body: Thanks for raising it! Just published a new version with this fix – 0.22.1

issue.title: support --environment in CLI
issue.body:
Closes #376. Adds an `--environment` option to the CLI with the following syntax, modelled after the syntax for `-g`:

``` bash
rollup -c --environment PRODUCTION,FOO:bar,BAZ:qux
```

This results in the following conditions inside the `rollup.config.js` file:

``` js
process.env.PRODUCTION === 'true'; // all process.env properties must be strings
process.env.FOO === 'bar';
process.env.BAZ === 'qux';
```

body:
@Rich-Harris I've tried this out in 0.22.2 and it appears to be generating bad code. You can [see in this example](http://rollupjs.org/#%7B%22options%22%3A%7B%22format%22%3A%22umd%22%2C%22moduleName%22%3A%22foo.bar%22%2C%22globals%22%3A%7B%7D%2C%22moduleId%22%3A%22%22%7D%2C%22modules%22%3A%5B%7B%22name%22%3A%22main.js%22%2C%22code%22%3A%22export%20default%2042%3B%22%7D%5D%7D).

The comma expression needs parens around it, otherwise it throws in a CommonJS or AMD environment.

issue.title: Fix UMD global export
issue.body:
This wraps the comma expression generated when using a namespaced global module name; e.g.: `Foo.bar`. Previously the generated code would fail in a CommonJS or AMD module environment.

See: https://github.com/rollup/rollup/issues/378#issuecomment-168063404

body: PR to address the above problem: https://github.com/rollup/rollup/pull/392
Is there any way to disable name-spaced UMD module names? Sometimes I just need a dot in exported name, like `1.0 `version in it. Thanks.
